dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Speak, speak!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Resolved, resolved!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: First, you know Caius Martius is chief enemy to the people.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: We know't, we know't!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price. Is't a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: No more talking on't; let it be done. Away, away!

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: One word, good citizens.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. What authority surfeits on would relieve us. If they would yield us but the superfluity while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely. But they think we are too dear. The leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularize their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them. Let us revenge this with our pikes ere we become rakes; for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Would you proceed especially against Caius Martius?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Against him first. He's a very dog to the commonalty.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Very well, and could be content to give him good report for't, but that he pays himself with being proud.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: I say unto you, what he hath done famously he did it to that end. Though soft-conscienced men can be content to say it was for his country, he did it to please his mother and to be partly proud, which he is, even to the altitude of his virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: What he cannot help in his nature you account a vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations. He hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.  What shouts are these? The other side o' th' city is risen. Why stay we prating here? To th' Capitol!

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Come, come!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Soft, who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Worthy Menenius Agrippa, one that hath always loved the people.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: He's one honest enough. Would all the rest were so!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? Where go you With bats and clubs? The matter? Speak, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Our business is not unknown to th' Senate. They have had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They say poor suitors have strong breaths; they shall know we have strong arms too.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours, Will you undo yourselves?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: We cannot, sir; we are undone already.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I tell you, friends, most charitable care Have the patricians of you. For your wants, Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them Against the Roman state, whose course will on The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs Of more strong link asunder than can ever Appear in your impediment. For the dearth, The gods, not the patricians, make it, and Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack, You are transported by calamity Thither where more attends you, and you slander The helms o' th' state, who care for you like fathers, When you curse them as enemies.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Care for us? True, indeed! They ne'er cared for us yet. Suffer us to famish, and their storehouses crammed with grain; make edicts for usury to support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily to chain up and restrain the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and there's all the love they bear us.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Either you must confess yourselves wondrous malicious Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you A pretty tale. It may be you have heard it, But since it serves my purpose, I will venture To stale't a little more.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Well, I'll hear it, sir; yet you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale. But, an't please you, deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: There was a time when all the body's members Rebelled against the belly, thus accused it: That only like a gulf it did remain I' th' midst o' th' body, idle and unactive, Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing Like labour with the rest, where th' other instruments Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel, And, mutually participate, did minister Unto the appetite and affection common Of the whole body. The belly answered-

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile, Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus- For, look you, I may make the belly smile As well as speak-it tauntingly replied To th' discontented members, the mutinous parts That envied his receipt; even so most fitly As you malign our senators for that They are not such as you.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Your belly's answer-what? The kingly crowned head, the vigilant eye, The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier, Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter, With other muniments and petty helps Is this our fabric, if that they-

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What then? 'Fore me, this fellow speaks. What then? What then?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Should by the cormorant belly be restrained, Who is the sink o' th' body-

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Well, what then?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: The former agents, if they did complain, What could the belly answer?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I will tell you, If you'll bestow a small-of what you have little- Patience awhile, you'st hear the belly's answer.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: You are long about it.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Note me this, good friend; Your most grave belly was deliberate, Not rash like his accusers, and thus answered: "True is it, my incorporate friends," quoth he, "That I receive the general food at first Which you do live upon; and fit it is, Because I am the storehouse and the shop Of the whole body. But, if you do remember, I send it through the rivers of your blood Even to the court, the heart, to th' seat o' th' brain; And, through the cranks and offices of man, The strongest nerves and small inferior veins From me receive that natural competency Whereby they live. And though that all at once, You, my good friends"-this says the belly, mark me-

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, well, well.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: "Though all at once cannot See what I do deliver out to each, Yet I can make my audit up, that all From me do back receive the flour of all, And leave me but the bran." What say you to't?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: It was an answer. How apply you this?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: The senators of Rome are this good belly, And you the mutinous members. For examine Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly Touching the weal o' th' common, you shall find No public benefit which you receive But it proceeds or comes from them to you And no way from yourselves. What do you think, You, the great toe of this assembly?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: I the great toe? Why the great toe?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: For that, being one o' th' lowest, basest, poorest, Of this most wise rebellion, thou goest foremost. Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run, Lead'st first to win some vantage. But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs. Rome and her rats are at the point of battle; The one side must have bale. Hail, noble Martius.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Thanks.-What's the matter, you dissentious rogues, That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, Make yourselves scabs?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: We have ever your good word.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: He that will give good words to thee will flatter Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs, That like nor peace nor war? The one affrights you; The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you hares; Where foxes, geese. You are no surer, no, Than is the coal of fire upon the ice Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is To make him worthy whose offence subdues him, And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate; and your affections are A sick man's appetite, who desires most that Which would increase his evil. He that depends Upon your favours swims with fins of lead, And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust ye? With every minute you do change a mind And call him noble that was now your hate, Him vile that was your garland. What's the matter, That in these several places of the city You cry against the noble senate, who, Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else Would feed on one another?-What's their seeking?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: For corn at their own rates, whereof they say The city is well stored.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Hang 'em! They say? They'll sit by th' fire and presume to know What's done i' th' Capitol, who's like to rise, Who thrives and who declines; side factions and give out Conjectural marriages, making parties strong And feebling such as stand not in their liking Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's grain enough? Would the nobility lay aside their ruth And let me use my sword, I'd make a quarry With thousands of these quartered slaves as high As I could pick my lance.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded; For though abundantly they lack discretion, Yet are they passing cowardly. But I beseech you, What says the other troop?

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: They are dissolved. Hang 'em! They said they were an-hungry, sighed forth proverbs That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat, That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not Corn for the rich men only. With these shreds They vented their complainings, which being answered And a petition granted them-a strange one, To break the heart of generosity And make bold power look pale-they threw their caps As they would hang them on the horns o' th' moon, Shouting their emulation.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What is granted them?

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms, Of their own choice. One's Junius Brutus, Sicinius Velutus, and I know not. 'Sdeath! The rabble should have first unroofed the city Ere so prevailed with me. It will in time Win upon power and throw forth greater themes For insurrection's arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: This is strange.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Go get you home, you fragments.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Where's Caius Martius?

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Here. What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: I am glad on't. Then we shall ha' means to vent Our musty superfluity. Enter Sicinius Velutus, Junius Brutus, two Tribunes; Cominius, Titus Lartius with other Senators. See, our best elders.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Martius, 'tis true that you have lately told us: The Volsces are in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: They have a leader, Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to't. I sin in envying his nobility, And, were I anything but what I am, I would wish me only he.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: You have fought together.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Were half to half the world by th' ears and he Upon my party, I'd revolt, to make Only my wars with him. He is a lion That I am proud to hunt.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Then, worthy Martius, Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: It is your former promise.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Sir, it is, And I am constant.-Titus Lartius, thou Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face. What, art thou stiff? Stand'st out?

dialogues.speaker: Titus Lartius
dialogues.line: No, Caius Martius, I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with th' other Ere stay behind this business.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: O, true bred!

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Your company to th' Capitol, where I know Our greatest friends attend us.

dialogues.speaker: Titus Lartius
dialogues.line: Lead you on. Follow Cominius. We must follow you; Right worthy your priority.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Noble Martius.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Hence to your homes, begone.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Nay, let them follow. The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutineers, Your valour puts well forth. Pray follow.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Was ever man so proud as is this Martius?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He has no equal.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: When we were chosen tribunes for the people-

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Marked you his lip and eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Nay, but his taunts.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Bemock the modest moon.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The present wars devour him! He is grown Too proud to be so valiant.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Such a nature, Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow Which he treads on at noon. But I do wonder His insolence can brook to be commanded Under Cominius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Fame, at the which he aims, In whom already he's well graced, cannot Better be held nor more attained than by A place below the first; for what miscarries Shall be the General's fault, though he perform To th' utmost of a man, and giddy censure Will then cry out of Martius "O, if he Had borne the business!"

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Besides, if things go well, Opinion that so sticks on Martius shall Of his demerits rob Cominius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come. Half all Cominius' honours are to Martius, Though Martius earned them not, and all his faults To Martius shall be honours, though indeed In aught he merit not.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Let's hence and hear How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion, More than in singularity, he goes Upon this present action.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Let's along.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: So, your opinion is, Aufidius, That they of Rome are entered in our counsels And know how we proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Is it not yours? What ever have been thought on in this state That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone Since I heard thence. These are the words-I think I have the letter here. Yes, here it is.  _They have pressed a power, but it is not known Whether for east or west. The dearth is great. The people mutinous; and, it is rumoured, Cominius, Martius your old enemy, Who is of Rome worse hated than of you,- And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman, These three lead on this preparation Whither 'tis bent. Most likely 'tis for you. Consider of it._

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Our army's in the field. We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready To answer us.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Nor did you think it folly To keep your great pretences veiled till when They needs must show themselves, which, in the hatching, It seemed, appeared to Rome. By the discovery We shall be shortened in our aim, which was To take in many towns ere almost Rome Should know we were afoot.

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: Noble Aufidius, Take your commission; hie you to your bands. Let us alone to guard Corioles. If they set down before's, for the remove Bring up your army. But I think you'll find They've not prepared for us.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: O, doubt not that; I speak from certainties. Nay, more, Some parcels of their power are forth already, And only hitherward. I leave your Honours. If we and Caius Martius chance to meet, 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike Till one can do no more.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: The gods assist you!

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: And keep your Honours safe!

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Farewell.

scenes.location: Rome. An apartment in Martius' house

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a more comfortable sort. If my son were my husband, I should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the embracements of his bed where he would show most love. When yet he was but tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not sell him an hour from her beholding, I, considering how honour would become such a person-that it was no better than picture-like to hang by th' wall, if renown made it not stir-was pleased to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he returned, his brows bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: But had he died in the business, madam, how then?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Then his good report should have been my son; I therein would have found issue. Hear me profess sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love alike and none less dear than thine and my good Martius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

dialogues.speaker: Gentlewoman
dialogues.line: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Indeed you shall not. Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum, See him pluck Aufidius down by th' hair; As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him. Methinks I see him stamp thus and call thus: "Come on, you cowards! You were got in fear, Though you were born in Rome." His bloody brow With his mailed hand then wiping, forth he goes Like to a harvestman that's tasked to mow Or all or lose his hire.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: His bloody brow? O Jupiter, no blood!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Away, you fool! It more becomes a man Than gilt his trophy. The breasts of Hecuba, When she did suckle Hector, looked not lovelier Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood At Grecian sword, contemning.-Tell Valeria We are fit to bid her welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: He'll beat Aufidius' head below his knee And tread upon his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: My ladies both, good day to you.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Sweet madam.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: I am glad to see your Ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: How do you both? You are manifest housekeepers. What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good faith. How does your little son?

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: I thank your Ladyship; well, good madam.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: He had rather see the swords and hear a drum than look upon his schoolmaster.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: O' my word, the father's son! I'll swear 'tis a very pretty boy. O' my troth, I looked upon him o' Wednesday half an hour together. H'as such a confirmed countenance. I saw him run after a gilded butterfly, and when he caught it, he let it go again, and after it again, and over and over he comes, and up again, catched it again. Or whether his fall enraged him or how 'twas, he did so set his teeth and tear it. O, I warrant how he mammocked it!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: One on's father's moods.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: A crack, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: Come, lay aside your stitchery. I must have you play the idle huswife with me this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: No, good madam, I will not out of doors.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: Not out of doors?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: She shall, she shall.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: Indeed, no, by your patience. I'll not over the threshold till my lord return from the wars.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably. Come, you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: I will wish her speedy strength and visit her with my prayers, but I cannot go thither.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Why, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: You would be another Penelope. Yet they say all the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths. Come, I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: In truth, la, go with me, and I'll tell you excellent news of your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: O, good madam, there can be none yet.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: Verily, I do not jest with you. There came news from him last night.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: Indeed, madam!

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: In earnest, it's true. I heard a senator speak it. Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth, against whom Cominius the General is gone with one part of our Roman power. Your lord and Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioles. They nothing doubt prevailing, and to make it brief wars. This is true, on mine honour, and so, I pray, go with us.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: Give me excuse, good madam. I will obey you in everything hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Let her alone, lady. As she is now, she will but disease our better mirth.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: In troth, I think she would.-Fare you well, then.-Come, good sweet lady.-Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy solemness out o' door, and go along with us.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: No, at a word, madam. Indeed I must not. I wish you much mirth.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: Well then, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: My horse to yours, no.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: 'Tis done.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Say, has our general met the enemy?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: They lie in view but have not spoke as yet.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: So the good horse is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: I'll buy him of you.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: No, I'll nor sell nor give him. Lend you him I will For half a hundred years.-Summon the town.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: How far off lie these armies?

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours. Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work, That we with smoking swords may march from hence To help our fielded friends!-Come, blow thy blast. Tullus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: No, nor a man that fears you less than he: That's lesser than a little. Hark, our drums Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls Rather than they shall pound us up. Our gates, Which yet seem shut, we have but pinned with rushes. They'll open of themselves. Hark you, far off! There is Aufidius. List what work he makes Amongst your cloven army.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: O, they are at it!

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Their noise be our instruction.-Ladders, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: They fear us not but issue forth their city.- Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight With hearts more proof than shields.-Advance, brave Titus. They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, Which makes me sweat with wrath.-Come on, my fellows! He that retires, I'll take him for a Volsce, And he shall feel mine edge.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: All the contagion of the south light on you, You shames of Rome! You herd of-Boils and plagues Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorred Farther than seen, and one infect another Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese, That bear the shapes of men, how have you run From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell! All hurt behind. Backs red, and faces pale With flight and agued fear! Mend, and charge home, Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe And make my wars on you. Look to't. Come on! If you'll stand fast we'll beat them to their wives, As they us to our trenches. Follow's!  So, now the gates are ope. Now prove good seconds! 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them, Not for the fliers. Mark me, and do the like.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Foolhardiness, not I.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Nor I.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: See, they have shut him in.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: To th' pot, I warrant him.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: What is become of Martius?

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Slain, sir, doubtless.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Following the fliers at the very heels, With them he enters, who upon the sudden Clapped to their gates. He is himself alone, To answer all the city.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: O noble fellow, Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword, And when it bows, stand'st up! Thou art left, Martius. A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art, Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible Only in strokes, but with thy grim looks and The thunderlike percussion of thy sounds Thou mad'st thine enemies shake, as if the world Were feverous and did tremble.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Look, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: O, 'tis Martius! Let's fetch him off or make remain alike.

dialogues.speaker: First Roman
dialogues.line: This will I carry to Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Second Roman
dialogues.line: And I this.

dialogues.speaker: Third Roman
dialogues.line: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: See here these movers that do prize their hours At a cracked drachma. Cushions, leaden spoons, Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves, Ere yet the fight be done, pack up. Down with them! And hark, what noise the General makes! To him! There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius, Piercing our Romans. Then, valiant Titus, take Convenient numbers to make good the city, Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste To help Cominius.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st. Thy exercise hath been too violent For a second course of fight.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Sir, praise me not. My work hath yet not warmed me. Fare you well. The blood I drop is rather physical Than dangerous to me. To Aufidius thus I will appear and fight.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Now the fair goddess Fortune Fall deep in love with thee, and her great charms Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman, Prosperity be thy page!

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Thy friend no less Than those she placeth highest! So farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Thou worthiest Martius! Go sound thy trumpet in the marketplace. Call thither all the officers o' th' town, Where they shall know our mind. Away!

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Breathe you, my friends. Well fought! We are come off Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands Nor cowardly in retire. Believe me, sirs, We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck, By interims and conveying gusts we have heard The charges of our friends. The Roman gods Lead their successes as we wish our own, That both our powers, with smiling fronts encount'ring, May give you thankful sacrifice! Thy news?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The citizens of Corioles have issued, And given to Lartius and to Martius battle. I saw our party to their trenches driven, And then I came away.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Though thou speakest truth, Methinks thou speak'st not well. How long is't since?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Above an hour, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums. How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour And bring thy news so late?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Spies of the Volsces Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel Three or four miles about; else had I, sir, Half an hour since brought my report.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Who's yonder, That does appear as he were flayed? O gods, He has the stamp of Martius, and I have Before-time seen him thus.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Come I too late?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor More than I know the sound of Martius' tongue From every meaner man.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Come I too late?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others, But mantled in your own.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: O, let me clip you In arms as sound as when I wooed, in heart As merry as when our nuptial day was done And tapers burned to bedward!

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Flower of warriors, how is't with Titus Lartius?

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: As with a man busied about decrees, Condemning some to death and some to exile; Ransoming him or pitying, threat'ning the other; Holding Corioles in the name of Rome Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash, To let him slip at will.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Where is that slave Which told me they had beat you to your trenches? Where's he? Call him hither.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Let him alone. He did inform the truth. But for our gentlemen, The common file-a plague! Tribunes for them!- The mouse ne'er shunned the cat as they did budge From rascals worse than they.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: But how prevailed you?

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Will the time serve to tell? I do not think. Where is the enemy? Are you lords o' th' field? If not, why cease you till you are so?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Martius, we have at disadvantage fought, And did retire to win our purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: How lies their battle? Know you on which side They have placed their men of trust?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: As I guess, Martius, Their bands i' th' vaward are the Antiates, Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius, Their very heart of hope.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: I do beseech you, By all the battles wherein we have fought, By th' blood we have shed together, by th' vows we have made To endure friends, that you directly set me Against Aufidius and his Antiates, And that you not delay the present, but, Filling the air with swords advanced and darts, We prove this very hour.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Though I could wish You were conducted to a gentle bath And balms applied to you, yet dare I never Deny your asking. Take your choice of those That best can aid your action.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Those are they That most are willing. If any such be here- As it were sin to doubt-that love this painting Wherein you see me smeared; if any fear Lesser his person than an ill report; If any think brave death outweighs bad life, And that his country's dearer than himself; Let him alone, or so many so minded, Wave thus to express his disposition And follow Martius.  O, me alone! Make you a sword of me? If these shows be not outward, which of you But is four Volsces? None of you but is Able to bear against the great Aufidius A shield as hard as his. A certain number, Though thanks to all, must I select from all. The rest shall bear the business in some other fight, As cause will be obeyed. Please you to march, And I shall quickly draw out my command, Which men are best inclined.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: March on, my fellows. Make good this ostentation, and you shall Divide in all with us.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: So, let the ports be guarded. Keep your duties As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch Those centuries to our aid; the rest will serve For a short holding. If we lose the field, We cannot keep the town.

dialogues.speaker: Lieutenant
dialogues.line: Fear not our care, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Hence, and shut your gates upon's. Our guider, come. To th' Roman camp conduct us.

scenes.location: A field of battle between the Roman and the Volscian camps

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: I'll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee Worse than a promise-breaker.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: We hate alike. Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Let the first budger die the other's slave, And the gods doom him after!

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: If I fly, Martius, Hollo me like a hare.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Alone I fought in your Corioles' walls, And made what work I pleased. 'Tis not my blood Wherein thou seest me masked. For thy revenge Wrench up thy power to th' highest.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Wert thou the Hector That was the whip of your bragged progeny, Thou shouldst not scape me here. Officious and not valiant, you have shamed me In your condemned seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work, Thou't not believe thy deeds. But I'll report it Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles; Where great patricians shall attend and shrug, I' th' end admire; where ladies shall be frighted And, gladly quaked, hear more; where the dull tribunes, That with the fusty plebeians hate thine honours, Shall say against their hearts "We thank the gods Our Rome hath such a soldier." Yet cam'st thou to a morsel of this feast, Having fully dined before.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: O general, Here is the steed, we the caparison. Hadst thou beheld-

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: Pray now, no more. My mother, Who has a charter to extol her blood, When she does praise me grieves me. I have done As you have done-that's what I can; Induced as you have been-that's for my country. He that has but effected his good will Hath overta'en mine act.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: You shall not be The grave of your deserving. Rome must know The value of her own. 'Twere a concealment Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement, To hide your doings and to silence that Which, to the spire and top of praises vouched, Would seem but modest. Therefore, I beseech you- In sign of what you are, not to reward What you have done-before our army hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: I have some wounds upon me, and they smart To hear themselves remembered.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Should they not, Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses- Whereof we have ta'en good and good store-of all The treasure in this field achieved and city, We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth Before the common distribution At your only choice.

dialogues.speaker: Martius
dialogues.line: I thank you, general, But cannot make my heart consent to take A bribe to pay my sword. I do refuse it; And stand upon my common part with those That have beheld the doing.  May these same instruments which, you profane, Never sound more! When drums and trumpets shall I' th' field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be Made all of false-faced soothing! When steel grows soft Soft as the parasite's silk, let him be made An ovator for the wars! No more, I say. For that I have not washed my nose that bled, Or foiled some debile wretch-which, without note, Here's many else have done-you shout me forth In acclamations hyperbolical, As if I loved my little should be dieted In praises sauced with lies.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Too modest are you, More cruel to your good report than grateful To us that give you truly. By your patience, If 'gainst yourself you be incensed, we'll put you, Like one that means his proper harm, in manacles, Then reason safely with you. Therefore be it known, As to us to all the world, that Caius Martius Wears this war's garland, in token of the which My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him, With all his trim belonging. And from this time, For what he did before Corioles, call him, With all th' applause and clamour of the host, Caius Martius Coriolanus! Bear Th' addition nobly ever!

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Caius Martius Coriolanus!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I will go wash; And when my face is fair, you shall perceive Whether I blush or no. Howbeit, I thank you. I mean to stride your steed and at all times To undercrest your good addition To th' fairness of my power.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: So, to our tent, Where, ere we do repose us, we will write To Rome of our success.-You, Titus Lartius, Must to Corioles back. Send us to Rome The best, with whom we may articulate For their own good and ours.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: I shall, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: The gods begin to mock me. I, that now Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg Of my lord general.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Take't, 'tis yours. What is't?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I sometime lay here in Corioles At a poor man's house; he used me kindly. He cried to me; I saw him prisoner; But then Aufidius was within my view, And wrath o'erwhelmed my pity. I request you To give my poor host freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: O, well begged! Were he the butcher of my son, he should Be free as is the wind.-Deliver him, Titus.

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: Martius, his name?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: By Jupiter, forgot! I am weary; yea, my memory is tired. Have we no wine here?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Go we to our tent. The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time It should be looked to. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: The town is ta'en.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: 'Twill be delivered back on good condition.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Condition? I would I were a Roman, for I cannot, Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition? What good condition can a treaty find I' th' part that is at mercy? Five times, Martius, I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter As often as we eat. By th' elements, If e'er again I meet him beard to beard, He's mine or I am his. Mine emulation Hath not that honour in't it had; for where I thought to crush him in an equal force, True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way, Or wrath or craft may get him.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: He's the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poisoned With only suff'ring stain by him; for him Shall fly out of itself. Nor sleep nor sanctuary, Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol, The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice, Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst My hate to Martius. Where I find him, were it At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, Against the hospitable canon, would I Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to th' city; Learn how 'tis held and what they are that must Be hostages for Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Will not you go?

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: I am attended at the cypress grove. I pray you- 'Tis south the city mills,-bring me word thither How the world goes, that to the pace of it I may spur on my journey.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: I shall, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good or bad?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Martius.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Pray you, who does the wolf love?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: The lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Ay, to devour him, as the hungry plebeians would the noble Martius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He's a lamb indeed, that baas like a bear.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two are old men; tell me one thing that I shall ask you.

dialogues.speaker: Both Tribunes
dialogues.line: Well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: In what enormity is Martius poor in, that you two have not in abundance?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Especially in pride.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: And topping all others in boasting.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: This is strange now. Do you two know how you are censured here in the city, I mean of us o' th' right-hand file, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Both Tribunes
dialogues.line: Why, how are we censured?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Because you talk of pride now, will you not be angry?

dialogues.speaker: Both Tribunes
dialogues.line: Well, well, sir, well?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience. Give your dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures, at the least, if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame Martius for being proud.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: We do it not alone, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I know you can do very little alone, for your helps are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single. Your abilities are too infantlike for doing much alone. You talk of pride. O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks and make but an interior survey of your good selves! O, that you could!

dialogues.speaker: Both Tribunes
dialogues.line: What then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Menenius, you are known well enough, too.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I am known to be a humorous patrician and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint, hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning. What I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath. Meeting two such wealsmen as you are-I cannot call you Lycurguses-if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it. I cannot say your Worships have delivered the matter well when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables. And though I must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you have good faces. If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too? What harm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough, too?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come, sir, come; we know you well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You know neither me, yourselves, nor anything. You are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs. You wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange-wife and a faucet-seller, and then rejourn the controversy of threepence to a second day of audience. When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers, set up the bloody flag against all patience, and, in roaring for a chamber pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding, the more entangled by your hearing. All the peace you make in their cause is calling both the parties knaves. You are a pair of strange ones.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come, come. You are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Our very priests must become mockers if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards, and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's cushion or to be entombed in an ass's packsaddle. Yet you must be saying Martius is proud, who, in a cheap estimation, is worth all your predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. Good e'en to your Worships. More of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians. I will be bold to take my leave of you. How now, my as fair as noble ladies-and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler-whither do you follow your eyes so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Honourable Menenius, my boy Martius approaches. For the love of Juno, let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Ha? Martius coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Ay, worthy Menenius, and with most prosperous approbation.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee! Hoo! Martius coming home? VALERIA, VIRGILIA. Nay, 'tis true.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Look, here's a letter from him. The state hath another, his wife another, and I think there's one at home for you.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I will make my very house reel tonight. A letter for me?

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: A letter for me? It gives me an estate of seven years' health, in which time I will make a lip at the physician. The most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic and, to this preservative, of no better report than a horse drench. Is he not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: O, no, no, no!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: O, he is wounded, I thank the gods for't.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: So do I too, if it be not too much. Brings he victory in his pocket, the wounds become him.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: On's brows, Menenius. He comes the third time home with the oaken garland.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Titus Lartius writes they fought together, but Aufidius got off.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that. An he had stayed by him, I would not have been so 'fidiused for all the chests in Corioles and the gold that's in them. Is the Senate possessed of this?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Good ladies, let's go.-Yes, yes, yes. The Senate has letters from the General, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war. He hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly.

dialogues.speaker: Valeria
dialogues.line: In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Wondrous? Ay, I warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: The gods grant them true.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: True? Pow, waw!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: True? I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded?  God save your good Worships! Martius is coming home; he has more cause to be proud.-Where is he wounded?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: I' th' shoulder and i' th' left arm. There will be large cicatrices to show the people when he shall stand for his place. He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' th' body.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: One i' th' neck and two i' th' thigh-there's nine that I know.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Now it's twenty-seven. Every gash was an enemy's grave. Hark, the trumpets!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: These are the ushers of Martius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears. Death, that dark spirit, in's nervy arm doth lie, Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die. crowned with an oaken garland, with Captains and Soldiers and a Herald. Trumpets sound.

dialogues.speaker: Herald
dialogues.line: Know, Rome, that all alone Martius did fight Within Corioles' gates, where he hath won, With fame, a name to Caius Martius; these In honour follows "Coriolanus." Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: No more of this, it does offend my heart. Pray now, no more.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Look, sir, your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: O, You have, I know, petitioned all the gods For my prosperity.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Nay, my good soldier, up. My gentle Martius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honour newly named- What is it? Coriolanus must I call thee? But, O, thy wife-

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: My gracious silence, hail. Wouldst thou have laughed had I come coffined home, That weep'st to see me triumph? Ah, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear And mothers that lack sons.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Now the gods crown thee!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: And live you yet?  O my sweet lady, pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: I know not where to turn. O, welcome home! And welcome, general.-And you're welcome all.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: A hundred thousand welcomes! I could weep, And I could laugh; I am light and heavy. Welcome. A curse begin at very root on's heart That is not glad to see thee! You are three That Rome should dote on; yet, by the faith of men, We have some old crab trees here at home that will not Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors! We call a nettle but a nettle, and The faults of fools but folly.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Ever right.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Menenius ever, ever.

dialogues.speaker: Herald
dialogues.line: Give way there, and go on!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Your hand, and yours. Ere in our own house I do shade my head, The good patricians must be visited, From whom I have received not only greetings, But with them change of honours.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy. Only There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but Our Rome will cast upon thee.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way Than sway with them in theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: On, to the Capitol. Brutus and Sicinius come forward.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights Are spectacled to see him. Your prattling nurse Into a rapture lets her baby cry While she chats him. The kitchen malkin pins Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck, Clamb'ring the walls to eye him. Stalls, bulks, windows Are smothered up, leads filled, and ridges horsed With variable complexions, all agreeing In earnestness to see him. Seld-shown flamens Do press among the popular throngs and puff To win a vulgar station. Our veiled dames Commit the war of white and damask in Their nicely-gauded cheeks to th' wanton spoil Of Phoebus' burning kisses. Such a pother, As if that whatsoever god who leads him Were slyly crept into his human powers And gave him graceful posture.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: On the sudden I warrant him consul.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Then our office may, During his power, go sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: He cannot temp'rately transport his honours From where he should begin and end, but will Lose those he hath won.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: In that there's comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Doubt not the commoners, for whom we stand, But they, upon their ancient malice will forget With the least cause these his new honours-which That he will give them make as little question As he is proud to do't.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I heard him swear, Were he to stand for consul, never would he Appear i' th' marketplace nor on him put The napless vesture of humility, Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds To th' people, beg their stinking breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: 'Tis right.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: It was his word. O, he would miss it rather Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him And the desire of the nobles.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: I wish no better Than have him hold that purpose and to put it In execution.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: 'Tis most like he will.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: It shall be to him then, as our good wills, A sure destruction.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: So it must fall out To him, or our authorities for an end. We must suggest the people in what hatred He still hath held them; that to's power he would Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders, and Dispropertied their freedoms; holding them In human action and capacity Of no more soul nor fitness for the world Than camels in their war, who have their provand Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows For sinking under them.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: This, as you say, suggested At some time when his soaring insolence Shall touch the people-which time shall not want If it be put upon't, and that's as easy As to set dogs on sheep-will be his fire To kindle their dry stubble, and their blaze Shall darken him for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought That Martius shall be consul. I have seen The dumb men throng to see him, and the blind to hear him speak; matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarves and handkerchiefs, Upon him as he passed; the nobles bended As to Jove's statue, and the Commons made A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts. I never saw the like.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Let's to the Capitol; And carry with us ears and eyes for th' time, But hearts for the event.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Have with you.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: Come, come. They are almost here. How many stand for consulships?

dialogues.speaker: Second Officer
dialogues.line: Three, they say; but 'tis thought of everyone Coriolanus will carry it.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: That's a brave fellow, but he's vengeance proud and loves not the common people.

dialogues.speaker: Second Officer
dialogues.line: 'Faith, there have been many great men that have flattered the people who ne'er loved them; and there be many that they have loved they know not wherefore; so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground. Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition and, out of his noble carelessness, lets them plainly see't.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm; but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than they can render it him and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite. Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.

dialogues.speaker: Second Officer
dialogues.line: He hath deserved worthily of his country, and his ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who, having been supple and courteous to the people, bonnetted, without any further deed to have them at all into their estimation and report; but he hath so planted his honours in their eyes and his actions in their hearts that for their tongues to be silent and not confess so much were a kind of ingrateful injury. To report otherwise were a malice that, giving itself the lie, would pluck reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: No more of him; he's a worthy man. Make way. They are coming. A sennet. Enter the Patricians and the Tribunes of the people, Lictors before them; Coriolanus, Menenius, Cominius the consul. The Patricians sit.  Sicinius and Brutus take their places by themselves. Coriolanus stands.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Having determined of the Volsces and To send for Titus Lartius, it remains, As the main point of this our after-meeting, To gratify his noble service that Hath thus stood for his country. Therefore please you, Most reverend and grave elders, to desire The present consul and last general In our well-found successes to report A little of that worthy work performed By Martius Caius Coriolanus, whom We met here both to thank and to remember With honours like himself.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Speak, good Cominius. Leave nothing out for length, and make us think Rather our state's defective for requital, Than we to stretch it out. Masters o' th' people, We do request your kindest ears and, after, Your loving motion toward the common body To yield what passes here.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: We are convented Upon a pleasing treaty and have hearts Inclinable to honour and advance The theme of our assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Which the rather We shall be blest to do if he remember A kinder value of the people than He hath hereto prized them at.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: That's off, that's off! I would you rather had been silent. Please you To hear Cominius speak?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Most willingly. But yet my caution was more pertinent Than the rebuke you give it.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: He loves your people, But tie him not to be their bedfellow.- Worthy Cominius, speak. Nay, keep your place.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Sit, Coriolanus. Never shame to hear What you have nobly done.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Your Honours, pardon. I had rather have my wounds to heal again Than hear say how I got them.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Sir, I hope My words disbenched you not?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: No, sir. Yet oft, When blows have made me stay, I fled from words. You soothed not, therefore hurt not; but your people, I love them as they weigh.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Pray now, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I had rather have one scratch my head i' th' sun When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monstered.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Masters of the people, Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter- That's thousand to one good one-when you now see He had rather venture all his limbs for honour Than one on's ears to hear it?-Proceed, Cominius.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: I shall lack voice. The deeds of Coriolanus Should not be uttered feebly. It is held That valour is the chiefest virtue and Most dignifies the haver; if it be, The man I speak of cannot in the world Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years, When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought Beyond the mark of others. Our then dictator, Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight When with his Amazonian chin he drove The bristled lips before him. He bestrid An o'erpressed Roman and i' th' Consul's view Slew three opposers. Tarquin's self he met And struck him on his knee. In that day's feats, When he might act the woman in the scene, He proved best man i' th' field and for his meed Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age Man-entered thus, he waxed like a sea, And in the brunt of seventeen battles since He lurched all swords of the garland. For this last, Before and in Corioles, let me say, I cannot speak him home. He stopped the flyers And by his rare example made the coward Turn terror into sport. As weeds before A vessel under sail, so men obeyed And fell below his stem. His sword, Death's stamp, Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot He was a thing of blood, whose every motion Was timed with dying cries. Alone he entered The mortal gate o' th' city, which he painted With shunless destiny; aidless came off And with a sudden reinforcement struck Corioles like a planet. Now all's his, When by and by the din of war gan pierce His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit Requickened what in flesh was fatigate, And to the battle came he, where he did Run reeking o'er the lives of men as if 'Twere a perpetual spoil; and till we called Both field and city ours, he never stood To ease his breast with panting.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Worthy man!

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: He cannot but with measure fit the honours Which we devise him.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Our spoils he kicked at; And looked upon things precious as they were The common muck of the world. He covets less Than misery itself would give, rewards His deeds with doing them, and is content To spend the time to end it.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: He's right noble. Let him be called for.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Call Coriolanus.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: He doth appear.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee consul.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I do owe them still My life and services.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: It then remains That you do speak to the people.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I do beseech you Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot Put on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them For my wounds' sake to give their suffrage. Please you That I may pass this doing.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Sir, the people Must have their voices; neither will they bate One jot of ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Put them not to't. Pray you, go fit you to the custom, and Take to you, as your predecessors have, Your honour with your form.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: It is a part That I shall blush in acting, and might well Be taken from the people.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Mark you that?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: To brag unto them, "thus I did, and thus!" Show them th' unaching scars which I should hide, As if I had received them for the hire Of their breath only!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Do not stand upon't.- We recommend to you, tribunes of the people, Our purpose to them, and to our noble consul Wish we all joy and honour.

dialogues.speaker: Senators
dialogues.line: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You see how he intends to use the people.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: May they perceive's intent! He will require them As if he did contemn what he requested Should be in them to give.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come, we'll inform them Of our proceedings here. On th' marketplace I know they do attend us.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: We may, sir, if we will.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no power to do; for, if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them. So, if he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful were to make a monster of the multitude, of the which we being members, should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: We have been called so of many; not that our heads are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald, but that our wits are so diversely coloured; and truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to all the points o' th' compass.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's will; 'tis strongly wedged up in a blockhead. But if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Why that way?

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience' sake, to help to get thee a wife.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: You are never without your tricks. You may, you may.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Are you all resolved to give your voices? But that's no matter; the greater part carries it. I say, if he would incline to the people, there was never a worthier man. Here he comes, and in the gown of humility. Mark his behaviour. We are not to stay all together, but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and by threes. He's to make his requests by particulars, wherein everyone of us has a single honour in giving him our own voices with our own tongues. Therefore follow me, and I'll direct you how you shall go by him.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Content, content.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: O sir, you are not right. Have you not known The worthiest men have done't?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: What must I say? "I pray, sir"-plague upon't! I cannot bring My tongue to such a pace. "Look, sir, my wounds! I got them in my country's service when Some certain of your brethren roared and ran From th' noise of our own drums."

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: O me, the gods! You must not speak of that. You must desire them To think upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Think upon me! Hang 'em! I would they would forget me, like the virtues Which our divines lose by 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You'll mar all. I'll leave you. Pray you speak to 'em, I pray you, In wholesome manner.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean. So, here comes a brace. You know the cause, sirs, of my standing here.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: We do, sir. Tell us what hath brought you to't.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Mine own desert.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Your own desert?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Ay, but not mine own desire.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: How, not your own desire?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: No, sir, 'twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: You must think if we give you anything, we hope to gain by you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Well then, I pray, your price o' th' consulship?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: The price is to ask it kindly.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Kindly, sir, I pray, let me ha't. I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private.-Your good voice, sir. What say you?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: You shall ha' it, worthy sir.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged. I have your alms. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: But this is something odd.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: An 'twere to give again-but 'tis no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Your enigma?

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have been a rod to her friends. You have not indeed loved the common people.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account gentle. And since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly. That is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you, I may be consul.

dialogues.speaker: Fifth Citizen
dialogues.line: We hope to find you our friend, and therefore give you our voices heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: You have received many wounds for your country.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I will make much of your voices and so trouble you no farther.

dialogues.speaker: Both Citizens
dialogues.line: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Most sweet voices! Better it is to die, better to starve, Than crave the hire which first we do deserve. Why in this wolvish toge should I stand here To beg of Hob and Dick that does appear Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't. What custom wills, in all things should we do't? The dust on antique time would lie unswept And mountainous error be too highly heaped For truth to o'erpeer. Rather than fool it so, Let the high office and the honour go To one that would do thus. I am half through; The one part suffered, the other will I do. Here come more voices. Your voices! For your voices I have fought; Watched for your voices; for your voices bear Of wounds two dozen odd. Battles thrice six I have seen and heard of; for your voices have Done many things, some less, some more. Your voices! Indeed, I would be consul.

dialogues.speaker: Sixth Citizen
dialogues.line: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Seventh Citizen
dialogues.line: Therefore let him be consul. The gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people!

dialogues.speaker: All Three Citizens
dialogues.line: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Worthy voices!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You have stood your limitation, and the Tribunes Endue you with the people's voice. Remains That in th' official marks invested, you Anon do meet the Senate.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Is this done?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: The custom of request you have discharged. The people do admit you, and are summoned To meet anon upon your approbation.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Where? At the Senate House?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: There, Coriolanus.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: May I change these garments?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: You may, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: That I'll straight do and, knowing myself again, Repair to th' Senate House.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I'll keep you company.-Will you along?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: We stay here for the people.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Fare you well. He has it now; and by his looks, methinks, 'Tis warm at his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: With a proud heart he wore His humble weeds. Will you dismiss the people?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: How now, my masters, have you chose this man?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: He has our voices, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice, He mocked us when he begged our voices.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Certainly, he flouted us downright.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: No, 'tis his kind of speech. He did not mock us.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says He used us scornfully. He should have showed us His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Why, so he did, I am sure.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: No, no. No man saw 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: He said he had wounds, which he could show in private, And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn, "I would be consul," says he; "aged custom, But by your voices, will not so permit me; Your voices therefore." When we granted that, Here was "I thank you for your voices. Thank you. Your most sweet voices! Now you have left your voices, I have no further with you." Was not this mockery?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Why either were you ignorant to see't Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness To yield your voices?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Could you not have told him As you were lessoned? When he had no power, But was a petty servant to the state, He was your enemy, ever spake against Your liberties and the charters that you bear I' th' body of the weal; and, now arriving A place of potency and sway o' th' state, If he should still malignantly remain Fast foe to th' plebeii, your voices might Be curses to yourselves. You should have said That as his worthy deeds did claim no less Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature Would think upon you for your voices, and Translate his malice towards you into love, Standing your friendly lord.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Thus to have said, As you were fore-advised, had touched his spirit And tried his inclination; from him plucked Either his gracious promise, which you might, As cause had called you up, have held him to; Or else it would have galled his surly nature, Which easily endures not article Tying him to aught. So putting him to rage, You should have ta'en th' advantage of his choler And passed him unelected.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you think That his contempt shall not be bruising to you When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies No heart among you? Or had you tongues to cry Against the rectorship of judgment?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
