dialogues.line: Have you ere now denied the asker, and now Again, of him that did not ask but mock, Bestow your sued-for tongues?

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: He's not confirmed. We may deny him yet.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: And will deny him. I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: I twice five hundred, and their friends to piece 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends They have chose a consul that will from them take Their liberties, make them of no more voice Than dogs that are as often beat for barking As therefore kept to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Let them assemble And, on a safer judgment, all revoke Your ignorant election. Enforce his pride And his old hate unto you. Besides, forget not With what contempt he wore the humble weed, How in his suit he scorned you; but your loves, Thinking upon his services, took from you Th' apprehension of his present portance, Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion After the inveterate hate he bears you.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Lay A fault on us, your tribunes, that we laboured, No impediment between, but that you must Cast your election on him.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Say you chose him More after our commandment than as guided By your own true affections, and that your minds, Preoccupied with what you rather must do Than what you should, made you against the grain To voice him consul. Lay the fault on us.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you, How youngly he began to serve his country, How long continued, and what stock he springs of, The noble house o' th' Martians, from whence came That Ancus Martius, Numa's daughter's son, Who, after great Hostilius here was king, Of the same house Publius and Quintus were, That our best water brought by conduits hither; And Censorinus, that was so surnamed, And nobly named so, twice being censor, Was his great ancestor.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: One thus descended, That hath beside well in his person wrought To be set high in place, we did commend To your remembrances; but you have found, Scaling his present bearing with his past, That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke Your sudden approbation.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Say you ne'er had done't- Harp on that still-but by our putting on. And presently when you have drawn your number, Repair to th' Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: We will so. Almost all Repent in their election.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Let them go on. This mutiny were better put in hazard Than stay, past doubt, for greater. If, as his nature is, he fall in rage With their refusal, both observe and answer The vantage of his anger.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: To th' Capitol, come. We will be there before the stream o' th' people, And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own, Which we have goaded onward.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: He had, my lord, and that it was which caused Our swifter composition.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: So then the Volsces stand but as at first, Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road Upon's again.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: They are worn, lord consul, so That we shall hardly in our ages see Their banners wave again.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Saw you Aufidius?

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: On safeguard he came to me, and did curse Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely Yielded the town. He is retired to Antium.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Spoke he of me?

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: He did, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: How? What?

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: How often he had met you sword to sword; That of all things upon the earth he hated Your person most; that he would pawn his fortunes To hopeless restitution, so he might Be called your vanquisher.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: At Antium lives he?

dialogues.speaker: Lartius
dialogues.line: At Antium.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home. Behold, these are the tribunes of the people, The tongues o' th' common mouth. I do despise them, For they do prank them in authority Against all noble sufferance.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Pass no further.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Ha? What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: It will be dangerous to go on. No further.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: What makes this change?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: The matter?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Hath he not passed the noble and the common?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Cominius, no.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Have I had children's voices?

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Tribunes, give way. He shall to the marketplace.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The people are incensed against him.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Stop, Or all will fall in broil.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Are these your herd? Must these have voices, that can yield them now And straight disclaim their tongues? What are your offices? You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth? Have you not set them on?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Be calm, be calm.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot, To curb the will of the nobility. Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule Nor ever will be ruled.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Call't not a plot. The people cry you mocked them; and, of late, When corn was given them gratis, you repined, Scandaled the suppliants for the people, called them Timepleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Why, this was known before.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Not to them all.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Have you informed them sithence?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: How? I inform them?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: You are like to do such business.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Not unlike, each way, to better yours.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds, Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me Your fellow tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: You show too much of that For which the people stir. If you will pass To where you are bound, you must inquire your way, Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit, Or never be so noble as a consul, Nor yoke with him for tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Let's be calm.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: The people are abused, set on. This palt'ring Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus Deserved this so dishonoured rub, laid falsely I' th' plain way of his merit.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Tell me of corn? This was my speech, and I will speak't again.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Not now, not now.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Not in this heat, sir, now.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends, I crave their pardons. For The mutable, rank-scented many, let them Regard me, as I do not flatter, and Therein behold themselves. I say again, In soothing them we nourish 'gainst our senate The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition, Which we ourselves have ploughed for, sowed, and scattered By mingling them with us, the honoured number, Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that Which they have given to beggars.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Well, no more.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: No more words, we beseech you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: How? No more? As for my country I have shed my blood, Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs Coin words till their decay against those measles Which we disdain should tetter us, yet sought The very way to catch them.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You speak o' th' people As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: 'Twere well We let the people know't.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What, what? His choler?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Choler? Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, 'twould be my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: "Shall remain"? Hear you this Triton of the minnows? Mark you His absolute "shall"?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: 'Twas from the canon.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: "Shall"? O good but most unwise patricians, why, You grave but reckless senators, have you thus Given Hydra leave to choose an officer, That with his peremptory "shall," being but The horn and noise o' th' monster's, wants not spirit To say he'll turn your current in a ditch And make your channel his? If he have power, Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake Your dangerous lenity. If you are learned, Be not as common fools; if you are not, Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians, If they be senators; and they are no less When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate, And such a one as he, who puts his "shall," His popular "shall," against a graver bench Than ever frowned in Greece. By Jove himself, It makes the consuls base! And my soul aches To know, when two authorities are up, Neither supreme, how soon confusion May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take The one by th' other.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Well, on to th' marketplace.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Whoever gave that counsel to give forth The corn o' th' storehouse gratis, as 'twas used Sometime in Greece-

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Well, well, no more of that.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Though there the people had more absolute power, I say they nourished disobedience, fed The ruin of the state.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why shall the people give One that speaks thus their voice?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I'll give my reasons, More worthier than their voices. They know the corn Was not our recompense, resting well assured They ne'er did service for't. Being pressed to th' war, Even when the navel of the state was touched, They would not thread the gates. This kind of service Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' th' war, Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they showed Most valour, spoke not for them. Th' accusation Which they have often made against the Senate, All cause unborn, could never be the native Of our so frank donation. Well, what then? How shall this bosom multitude digest The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express What's like to be their words: "We did request it; We are the greater poll, and in true fear They gave us our demands." Thus we debase The nature of our seats and make the rabble Call our cares fears, which will in time Break ope the locks o' th' Senate and bring in The crows to peck the eagles.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Come, enough.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Enough, with over-measure.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: No, take more! What may be sworn by, both divine and human, Seal what I end withal! This double worship- Where one part does disdain with cause, the other Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom Cannot conclude but by the yea and no Of general ignorance-it must omit Real necessities and give way the while To unstable slightness. Purpose so barred, it follows Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you- You that will be less fearful than discreet, That love the fundamental part of state More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer A noble life before a long, and wish To jump a body with a dangerous physic That's sure of death without it-at once pluck out The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick The sweet which is their poison. Your dishonour Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state Of that integrity which should become't, Not having the power to do the good it would For th' ill which doth control't.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: 'Has said enough.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: 'Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer As traitors do.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee! What should the people do with these bald tribunes, On whom depending, their obedience fails To th' greater bench. In a rebellion, When what's not meet but what must be was law, Then were they chosen. In a better hour, Let what is meet be said it must be meet, And throw their power i' th' dust.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Manifest treason.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: This a consul? No.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The aediles, ho! Let him be apprehended.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Go call the people; in whose name myself Attach thee as a traitorous innovator, A foe to th' public weal. Obey, I charge thee, And follow to thine answer.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Hence, old goat.

dialogues.speaker: All Patricians
dialogues.line: We'll surety him.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Aged sir, hands off.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Hence, rotten thing, or I shall shake thy bones Out of thy garments.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Help, ye citizens!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: On both sides more respect!

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Here's he that would take from you all your power.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Seize him, aediles.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: Down with him, down with him!

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: Weapons, weapons, weapons! Tribunes, patricians, citizens, what, ho! Sicinius, Brutus, Coriolanus, citizens!

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Peace, peace, peace! Stay, hold, peace!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What is about to be? I am out of breath. Confusion's near. I cannot speak. You tribunes To th' people!-Coriolanus, patience!- Speak, good Sicinius.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Hear me, people! Peace!

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: Let's hear our tribune. Peace! Speak, speak, speak.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: You are at point to lose your liberties. Martius would have all from you, Martius, Whom late you have named for consul.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Fie, fie, fie! This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: What is the city but the people?

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: True, The people are the city.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: By the consent of all, we were established The people's magistrates.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: You so remain.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: And so are like to do.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: That is the way to lay the city flat, To bring the roof to the foundation And bury all which yet distinctly ranges In heaps and piles of ruin.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: This deserves death.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Or let us stand to our authority Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce, Upon the part o' th' people, in whose power We were elected theirs, Martius is worthy Of present death.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Therefore lay hold of him, Bear him to th' rock Tarpeian, and from thence Into destruction cast him.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Aediles, seize him!

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: Yield, Martius, yield!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Hear me one word. Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.

dialogues.speaker: Aediles
dialogues.line: Peace, peace!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Be that you seem, truly your country's friend, And temp'rately proceed to what you would Thus violently redress.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Sir, those cold ways, That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous Where the disease is violent.-Lay hands upon him, And bear him to the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: No; I'll die here. There's some among you have beheld me fighting. Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Down with that sword!-Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Lay hands upon him!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Help Martius, help! You that be noble, help him, young and old!

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: Down with him, down with him!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Go, get you to your house. Begone, away. All will be naught else.

dialogues.speaker: Second Senator
dialogues.line: Get you gone.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Stand fast! We have as many friends as enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Shall it be put to that?

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: The gods forbid! I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house; Leave us to cure this cause.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: For 'tis a sore upon us You cannot tent yourself. Begone, beseech you.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Come, sir, along with us.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I would they were barbarians, as they are, Though in Rome littered, not Romans, as they are not, Though calved i' th' porch o' th' Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Begone! Put not your worthy rage into your tongue. One time will owe another.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: On fair ground I could beat forty of them.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I could myself Take up a brace o' th' best of them, yea, the two tribunes.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic, And manhood is called foolery when it stands Against a falling fabric. Will you hence, Before the tag return, whose rage doth rend Like interrupted waters, and o'erbear What they are used to bear?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Pray you, begone. I'll try whether my old wit be in request With those that have but little. This must be patched With cloth of any colour.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Nay, come away.

dialogues.speaker: Patrician
dialogues.line: This man has marred his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: His nature is too noble for the world. He would not flatter Neptune for his trident Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth; What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent, And, being angry, does forget that ever He heard the name of death. Here's goodly work.

dialogues.speaker: Patrician
dialogues.line: I would they were abed!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance, Could he not speak 'em fair?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Where is this viper That would depopulate the city and Be every man himself?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You worthy tribunes-

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock With rigorous hands. He hath resisted law, And therefore law shall scorn him further trial Than the severity of the public power Which he so sets at naught.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: He shall well know The noble tribunes are the people's mouths, And we their hands.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: He shall, sure on't.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Sir, sir-

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Peace!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Do not cry havoc where you should but hunt With modest warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Sir, how comes't that you Have holp to make this rescue?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Hear me speak. As I do know the Consul's worthiness, So can I name his faults.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Consul? What consul?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: The consul Coriolanus.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He consul?

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: No, no, no, no, no!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: If, by the Tribunes' leave, and yours, good people, I may be heard, I would crave a word or two, The which shall turn you to no further harm Than so much loss of time.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Speak briefly then, For we are peremptory to dispatch This viperous traitor. To eject him hence Were but one danger, and to keep him here Our certain death. Therefore it is decreed He dies tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Now the good gods forbid That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude Towards her deserved children is enrolled In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam Should now eat up her own.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: He's a disease that must be cut away.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: O, he's a limb that has but a disease- Mortal to cut it off; to cure it easy. What has he done to Rome that's worthy death? Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost- Which I dare vouch is more than that he hath By many an ounce-he dropt it for his country; And what is left, to lose it by his country Were to us all, that do't and suffer it A brand to th' end o' th' world.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: This is clean cam.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Merely awry. When he did love his country, It honoured him.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: The service of the foot, Being once gangrened, is not then respected For what before it was.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: We'll hear no more. Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence, Lest his infection, being of catching nature, Spread further.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: One word more, one word! This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find The harm of unscanned swiftness, will too late, Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process, Lest parties-as he is beloved-break out And sack great Rome with Romans.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: If it were so-

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: What do ye talk? Have we not had a taste of his obedience? Our aediles smote! Ourselves resisted? Come.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Consider this: he has been bred i' th' wars Since he could draw a sword, and is ill schooled In bolted language; meal and bran together He throws without distinction. Give me leave, I'll go to him and undertake to bring him Where he shall answer by a lawful form, In peace, to his utmost peril.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Noble tribunes, It is the humane way: the other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Noble Menenius, Be you then as the people's officer.- Masters, lay down your weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Go not home.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Meet on the marketplace. We'll attend you there, Where if you bring not Martius, we'll proceed In our first way.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I'll bring him to you.  Let me desire your company. He must come, Or what is worst will follow.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Pray you, let's to him.

scenes.location: Rome. A room in Coriolanus's house

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Let them pull all about mine ears, present me Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels, Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock, That the precipitation might down stretch Below the beam of sight, yet will I still Be thus to them.

dialogues.speaker: First Patrician
dialogues.line: You do the nobler.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I muse my mother Does not approve me further, who was wont To call them woollen vassals, things created To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads In congregations, to yawn, be still, and wonder When one but of my ordinance stood up To speak of peace or war. I talk of you. Why did you wish me milder? Would you have me False to my nature? Rather say I play The man I am.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: O, sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on Before you had worn it out.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Let go.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: You might have been enough the man you are With striving less to be so. Lesser had been The thwartings of your dispositions if You had not showed them how ye were disposed Ere they lacked power to cross you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Let them hang!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Ay, and burn too.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough. You must return and mend it.

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: There's no remedy, Unless, by not so doing, our good city Cleave in the midst and perish.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Pray be counselled. I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of anger To better vantage.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Well said, noble woman. Before he should thus stoop to th' herd-but that The violent fit o' th' time craves it as physic For the whole state-I would put mine armour on, Which I can scarcely bear.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: What must I do?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Return to th' Tribunes.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Well, what then? What then?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Repent what you have spoke.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: For them? I cannot do it to the gods. Must I then do't to them?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: You are too absolute, Though therein you can never be too noble But when extremities speak. I have heard you say Honour and policy, like unsevered friends, I' th' war do grow together. Grant that, and tell me In peace what each of them by th' other lose That they combine not there.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Tush, tush!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: A good demand.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: If it be honour in your wars to seem The same you are not, which for your best ends You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse That it shall hold companionship in peace With honour as in war, since that to both It stands in like request?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Why force you this?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Because that now it lies you on to speak To th' people, not by your own instruction, Nor by th' matter which your heart prompts you, But with such words that are but rooted in Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables Of no allowance to your bosom's truth. Now, this no more dishonours you at all Than to take in a town with gentle words, Which else would put you to your fortune and The hazard of much blood. I would dissemble with my nature where My fortunes and my friends at stake required I should do so in honour. I am in this Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles; And you will rather show our general louts How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard Of what that want might ruin.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Noble lady!- Come, go with us; speak fair. You may salve so, Not what is dangerous present, but the loss Of what is past.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: I prithee now, my son, Go to them with this bonnet in thy hand, And thus far having stretched it-here be with them- Thy knee bussing the stones-for in such busines Action is eloquence, and the eyes of th' ignorant More learned than the ears-waving thy head, Which often thus correcting thy stout heart, Now humble as the ripest mulberry That will not hold the handling. Or say to them Thou art their soldier and, being bred in broils, Hast not the soft way, which thou dost confess Were fit for thee to use, as they to claim, In asking their good loves; but thou wilt frame Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far As thou hast power and person.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: This but done Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours; For they have pardons, being asked, as free As words to little purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Prithee now, Go, and be ruled; although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: I have been i' th' marketplace; and, sir, 'tis fit You make strong party or defend yourself By calmness or by absence. All's in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Only fair speech.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: I think 'twill serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: He must, and will.- Prithee, now, say you will, and go about it.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce? Must I With my base tongue give to my noble heart A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do't. Yet, were there but this single plot to lose, This mould of Martius, they to dust should grind it And throw't against the wind. To th' marketplace! You have put me now to such a part which never I shall discharge to th' life.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Come, come, we'll prompt you.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said My praises made thee first a soldier, so, To have my praise for this, perform a part Thou hast not done before.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Well, I must do't. Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlot's spirit! My throat of war be turned, Which choired with my drum, into a pipe Small as an eunuch or the virgin voice That babies lulls asleep! The smiles of knaves Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up The glasses of my sight! A beggar's tongue Make motion through my lips, and my armed knees, Who bowed but in my stirrup, bend like his That hath received an alms! I will not do't, Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth And, by my body's action, teach my mind A most inherent baseness.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: At thy choice, then. To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour Than thou of them. Come all to ruin. Let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list. Thy valiantness was mine; thou suck'dst it from me, But owe thy pride thyself.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Pray, be content. Mother, I am going to the marketplace. Chide me no more. I'll mountebank their loves, Cog their hearts from them, and come home beloved Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going. Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul, Or never trust to what my tongue can do I' th' way of flattery further.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Do your will.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Away! The Tribunes do attend you. Arm yourself To answer mildly, for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: The word is "mildly." Pray you, let us go. Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honour.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Ay, but mildly.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Well, mildly be it, then. Mildly.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: In this point charge him home, that he affects Tyrannical power. If he evade us there, Enforce him with his envy to the people, And that the spoil got on the Antiates Was ne'er distributed. What, will he come?

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: He's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: How accompanied?

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: With old Menenius, and those senators That always favoured him.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Have you a catalogue Of all the voices that we have procured, Set down by th' poll?

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: I have. 'Tis ready.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Have you collected them by tribes?

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Assemble presently the people hither; And when they hear me say "It shall be so I' th' right and strength o' th' commons," be it either For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them If I say "Fine," cry "Fine," if "Death," cry "Death," Insisting on the old prerogative And power i' th' truth o' th' cause.

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: I shall inform them.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: And when such time they have begun to cry, Let them not cease, but with a din confused Enforce the present execution Of what we chance to sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Make them be strong and ready for this hint When we shall hap to give't them.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Go about it. Put him to choler straight. He hath been used Ever to conquer and to have his worth Of contradiction. Being once chafed, he cannot Be reined again to temperance; then he speaks What's in his heart; and that is there which looks With us to break his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Well, here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Calmly, I do beseech you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Ay, as an ostler, that for th' poorest piece Will bear the knave by th' volume.-Th' honoured gods Keep Rome in safety and the chairs of justice Supplied with worthy men! Plant love among's! Throng our large temples with the shows of peace And not our streets with war!

dialogues.speaker: First Senator
dialogues.line: Amen, amen.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: A noble wish.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Draw near, ye people.

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: List to your tribunes. Audience! Peace, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: First, hear me speak.

dialogues.speaker: Both Tribunes
dialogues.line: Well, say.-Peace, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Shall I be charged no further than this present? Must all determine here?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: I do demand If you submit you to the people's voices, Allow their officers, and are content To suffer lawful censure for such faults As shall be proved upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I am content.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Lo, citizens, he says he is content. The warlike service he has done, consider. Think Upon the wounds his body bears, which show Like graves i' th' holy churchyard.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Scratches with briars, Scars to move laughter only.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Consider further, That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier. Do not take His rougher accents for malicious sounds, But, as I say, such as become a soldier Rather than envy you.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Well, well, no more.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: What is the matter, That, being passed for consul with full voice, I am so dishonoured that the very hour You take it off again?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Answer to us.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Say then. 'Tis true, I ought so.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: We charge you that you have contrived to take From Rome all seasoned office and to wind Yourself into a power tyrannical, For which you are a traitor to the people.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: How? Traitor?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Nay, temperately! Your promise.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: The fires i' th' lowest hell fold in the people! Call me their traitor? Thou injurious tribune! In thy hands clutched as many millions, in Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say "Thou liest" unto thee with a voice as free As I do pray the gods.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Mark you this, people?

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: To th' rock, to th' rock with him!

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Peace! We need not put new matter to his charge. What you have seen him do and heard him speak, Beating your officers, cursing yourselves, Opposing laws with strokes, and here defying Those whose great power must try him-even this, So criminal and in such capital kind, Deserves th' extremest death.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: But since he hath Served well for Rome-

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: What do you prate of service?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I talk of that that know it.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: You?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Is this the promise that you made your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Know, I pray you-

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I'll know no further. Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death, Vagabond exile, flaying, pent to linger But with a grain a day, I would not buy Their mercy at the price of one fair word, Nor check my courage for what they can give, To have't with saying "Good morrow."

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: For that he has, As much as in him lies, from time to time Envied against the people, seeking means To pluck away their power, as now at last Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers That do distribute it, in the name o' th' people And in the power of us the Tribunes, we, Even from this instant, banish him our city In peril of precipitation From off the rock Tarpeian, never more To enter our Rome gates. I' th' people's name, I say it shall be so.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: It shall be so, it shall be so! Let him away! He's banished, and it shall be so.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Hear me, my masters and my common friends-

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: He's sentenced. No more hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Let me speak. I have been consul and can show for Rome Her enemies' marks upon me. I do love My country's good with a respect more tender, More holy and profound, than mine own life, My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase, And treasure of my loins. Then if I would Speak that-

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: We know your drift. Speak what?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: There's no more to be said, but he is banished As enemy to the people and his country. It shall be so.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: It shall be so, it shall be so!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: You common cry of curs, whose breath I hate As reek o' th' rotten fens, whose loves I prize As the dead carcasses of unburied men That do corrupt my air, I banish you! And here remain with your uncertainty; Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts; Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes, Fan you into despair! Have the power still To banish your defenders, till at length Your ignorance-which finds not till it feels, Making but reservation of yourselves, Still your own foes-deliver you, As most abated captives to some nation That won you without blows! Despising For you the city, thus I turn my back. There is a world elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: The people's enemy is gone, is gone.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: Our enemy is banished; he is gone. Hoo, hoo!

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Go see him out at gates, and follow him, As he hath followed you, with all despite. Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard Attend us through the city.

dialogues.speaker: All Plebeians
dialogues.line: Come, come, let's see him out at gates! Come! The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.

scenes.location: Rome. Before a gate of the city

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Come, leave your tears. A brief farewell. The beast With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother, Where is your ancient courage? You were used To say extremities was the trier of spirits; That common chances common men could bear; That when the sea was calm, all boats alike Showed mastership in floating; fortune's blows When most struck home, being gentle wounded craves A noble cunning. You were used to load me With precepts that would make invincible The heart that conned them.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: O heavens! O heavens!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Nay, I prithee, woman-

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome, And occupations perish!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: What, what, what! I shall be loved when I am lacked. Nay, mother, Resume that spirit when you were wont to say If you had been the wife of Hercules, Six of his labours you'd have done and saved Your husband so much sweat.-Cominius, Droop not. Adieu.-Farewell, my wife, my mother. I'll do well yet.-Thou old and true Menenius, Thy tears are salter than a younger man's And venomous to thine eyes.-My sometime general, I have seen thee stern, and thou hast oft beheld Heart-hard'ning spectacles. Tell these sad women 'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes As 'tis to laugh at 'em.-My mother, you wot well My hazards still have been your solace, and- Believe't not lightly-though I go alone, Like to a lonely dragon that his fen Makes feared and talked of more than seen, your son Will or exceed the common or be caught With cautelous baits and practice.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: My first son, Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius With thee awhile. Determine on some course More than a wild exposture to each chance That starts i' th' way before thee.

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: O the gods!

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us And we of thee; so if the time thrust forth A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send O'er the vast world to seek a single man And lose advantage, which doth ever cool I' th' absence of the needer.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Fare ye well. Thou hast years upon thee, and thou art too full Of the wars' surfeits to go rove with one That's yet unbruised. Bring me but out at gate.- Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and My friends of noble touch. When I am forth, Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come. While I remain above the ground, you shall Hear from me still, and never of me aught But what is like me formerly.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: That's worthily As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep. If I could shake off but one seven years From these old arms and legs, by the good gods, I'd with thee every foot.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Give me thy hand. Come.

scenes.location: Rome. A street near the gate

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Bid them all home. He's gone, and we'll no further. The nobility are vexed, whom we see have sided In his behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Now we have shown our power, Let us seem humbler after it is done Than when it was a-doing.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Bid them home. Say their great enemy is gone, and they Stand in their ancient strength.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Dismiss them home. Here comes his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Let's not meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: They say she's mad.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: They have ta'en note of us. Keep on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: O, you're well met. The hoarded plague o' th' gods Requite your love!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Peace, peace! Be not so loud.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: If that I could for weeping, you should hear- Nay, and you shall hear some.  Will you be gone?

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: You shall stay too. I would I had the power To say so to my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Are you mankind?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Ay, fool, is that a shame? Note but this, fool. Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship To banish him that struck more blows for Rome Than thou hast spoken words?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: O blessed heavens!

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: More noble blows than ever thou wise words, And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what-yet go. Nay, but thou shalt stay too. I would my son Were in Arabia and thy tribe before him, His good sword in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Virgilia
dialogues.line: What then? He'd make an end of thy posterity.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Bastards and all. Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Come, come, peace.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: I would he had continued to his country As he began, and not unknit himself The noble knot he made.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I would he had.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: "I would he had?" 'Twas you incensed the rabble. Cats, that can judge as fitly of his worth As I can of those mysteries which heaven Will not have Earth to know.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Pray, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Now, pray, sir, get you gone. You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this: As far as doth the Capitol exceed The meanest house in Rome, so far my son- This lady's husband here, this, do you see?- Whom you have banished, does exceed you all.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Well, well, we'll leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Why stay we to be baited With one that wants her wits?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Take my prayers with you. I would the gods had nothing else to do But to confirm my curses. Could I meet 'em But once a day, it would unclog my heart Of what lies heavy to't.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You have told them home, And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?

dialogues.speaker: Volumnia
dialogues.line: Anger's my meat. I sup upon myself And so shall starve with feeding. Come, let's go. Leave this faint puling, and lament as I do, In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Fie, fie, fie!

scenes.location: A highway between Rome and Antium

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: I know you well, sir, and you know me. Your name I think is Adrian.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: It is so, sir. Truly, I have forgot you.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: I am a Roman, and my services are, as you are, against 'em. Know you me yet?

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: Nicanor, no?

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: The same, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: You had more beard when I last saw you, but your favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state to find you out there. You have well saved me a day's journey.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: There hath been in Rome strange insurrections, the people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: Hath been? Is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so. They are in a most warlike preparation and hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing would make it flame again; for the nobles receive so to heart the banishment of that worthy Coriolanus that they are in a ripe aptness to take all power from the people and to pluck from them their tribunes for ever. This lies glowing, I can tell you, and is almost mature for the violent breaking out.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: Coriolanus banished?

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: Banished, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: The day serves well for them now. I have heard it said the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is when she's fallen out with her husband. Your noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his great opposer Coriolanus being now in no request of his country.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: He cannot choose. I am most fortunate thus accidentally to encounter you. You have ended my business, and I will merrily accompany you home.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: I shall between this and supper tell you most strange things from Rome, all tending to the good of their adversaries. Have you an army ready, say you?

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: A most royal one. The centurions and their charges, distinctly billeted, already in th' entertainment, and to be on foot at an hour's warning.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: I am joyful to hear of their readiness and am the man, I think, that shall set them in present action. So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of your company.

dialogues.speaker: Volsce
dialogues.line: You take my part from me, sir. I have the most cause to be glad of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Roman
dialogues.line: Well, let us go together.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: A goodly city is this Antium. City, 'Tis I that made thy widows. Many an heir Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars Have I heard groan and drop. Then know me not, Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones In puny battle slay me. Save you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Citizen
dialogues.line: And you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Direct me, if it be your will, Where great Aufidius lies. Is he in Antium?

dialogues.speaker: Citizen
dialogues.line: He is, and feasts the nobles of the state At his house this night.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Which is his house, beseech you?

dialogues.speaker: Citizen
dialogues.line: This here before you.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Thank you, sir. Farewell. O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn, Whose double bosoms seems to wear one heart, Whose hours, whose bed, whose meal and exercise Are still together, who twin, as 'twere, in love Unseparable, shall within this hour, On a dissension of a doit, break out To bitterest enmity; so fellest foes, Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep To take the one the other, by some chance, Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends And interjoin their issues. So with me: My birthplace hate I, and my love's upon This enemy town. I'll enter. If he slay me, He does fair justice; if he give me way, I'll do his country service.

scenes.location: Antium. A hall in Aufidius's house

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Wine, wine, wine! What service is here? I think our fellows are asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Where's Cotus? My master calls for him. Cotus!

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: A goodly house. The feast smells well, but I Appear not like a guest.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: What would you have, friend? Whence are you? Here's no place for you. Pray go to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I have deserved no better entertainment In being Coriolanus.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Whence are you, sir?-Has the porter his eyes in his head, that he gives entrance to such companions?-Pray, get you out.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Away!

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Away? Get you away.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Now th' art troublesome.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Are you so brave? I'll have you talked with anon. Enter Third  Servingman; the First, entering, meets him.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: What fellow's this?

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: A strange one as ever I looked on. I cannot get him out o' th' house. Prithee call my master to him.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid the house.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Let me but stand. I will not hurt your hearth.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: What are you?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: A gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: A marv'llous poor one.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: True, so I am.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other station. Here's no place for you. Pray you, avoid. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: What, you will not?-Prithee, tell my master what a strange guest he has here.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: And I shall.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Where dwell'st thou?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Under the canopy.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Under the canopy?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: I' th' city of kites and crows.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: I' th' city of kites and crows? What an ass it is! Then thou dwell'st with daws too?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: No, I serve not thy master.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: How, sir? Do you meddle with my master?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Ay, 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy mistress. Thou prat'st and prat'st. Serve with thy trencher, hence!

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Where is this fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Here, sir. I'd have beaten him like a dog, but for disturbing the lords

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Whence com'st thou? What wouldst thou? Thy name? Why speak'st not? Speak, man. What's thy name?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: If, Tullus, Not yet thou know'st me, and, seeing me, dost not Think me for the man I am, necessity Commands me name myself.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: What is thy name?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears And harsh in sound to thine.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Say, what's thy name? Thou has a grim appearance, and thy face Bears a command in't. Though thy tackle's torn, Thou show'st a noble vessel. What's thy name?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: Prepare thy brow to frown. Know'st thou me yet?

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: I know thee not. Thy name?

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: My name is Caius Martius, who hath done To thee particularly and to all the Volsces Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may My surname Coriolanus. The painful service, The extreme dangers, and the drops of blood Shed for my thankless country are requited But with that surname, a good memory And witness of the malice and displeasure Which thou shouldst bear me. Only that name remains. The cruelty and envy of the people, Permitted by our dastard nobles, who Have all forsook me, hath devoured the rest, And suffered me by th' voice of slaves to be Whooped out of Rome. Now this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth, not out of hope- Mistake me not-to save my life; for if I had feared death, of all the men i' th' world I would have 'voided thee, but in mere spite, To be full quit of those my banishers, Stand I before thee here. Then if thou hast A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims Of shame seen through thy country, speed thee straight And make my misery serve thy turn. So use it That my revengeful services may prove As benefits to thee, for I will fight Against my cankered country with the spleen Of all the under fiends. But if so be Thou dar'st not this, and that to prove more fortunes Thou 'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am Longer to live most weary, and present My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice, Which not to cut would show thee but a fool, Since I have ever followed thee with hate, Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast, And cannot live but to thy shame, unless It be to do thee service.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: O Martius, Martius, Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter Should from yond cloud speak divine things And say 'tis true, I'd not believe them more Than thee, all-noble Martius. Let me twine Mine arms about that body, whereagainst My grained ash an hundred times hath broke And scarred the moon with splinters. Here I clip The anvil of my sword and do contest As hotly and as nobly with thy love As ever in ambitious strength I did Contend against thy valour. Know thou first, I loved the maid I married; never man Sighed truer breath. But that I see thee here, Thou noble thing, more dances my rapt heart Than when I first my wedded mistress saw Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars, I tell thee We have a power on foot, and I had purpose Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn Or lose mine arm for't. Thou hast beat me out Twelve several times, and I have nightly since Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me; We have been down together in my sleep, Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat, And waked half dead with nothing. Worthy Martius, Had we no other quarrel else to Rome but that Thou art thence banished, we would muster all From twelve to seventy and, pouring war Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome, Like a bold flood o'erbear 't. O, come, go in, And take our friendly senators by th' hands, Who now are here, taking their leaves of me, Who am prepared against your territories, Though not for Rome itself.

dialogues.speaker: Coriolanus
dialogues.line: You bless me, gods!

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have The leading of thine own revenges, take Th' one half of my commission and set down- As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st Thy country's strength and weakness-thine own ways, Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, Or rudely visit them in parts remote To fright them ere destroy. But come in. Let me commend thee first to those that shall Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes! And more a friend than e'er an enemy- Yet, Martius, that was much. Your hand. Most welcome! Two of the Servingmen come forward.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Here's a strange alteration!

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with a cudgel, and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a false report of him.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: What an arm he has! He turned me about with his finger and his thumb as one would set up a top.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in him. He had, sir, a kind of face, methought-I cannot tell how to term it.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: He had so, looking as it were-Would I were hanged, but I thought there was more in him than I could think.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: So did I, I'll be sworn. He is simply the rarest man i' th' world.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: I think he is. But a greater soldier than he you wot one.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Who, my master?

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Nay, it's no matter for that.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Worth six on him.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Nay, not so neither. But I take him to be the greater soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that. For the defence of a town our general is excellent.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Ay, and for an assault too.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: O slaves, I can tell you news, news, you rascals! FIRST and SECOND SERVINGMAN. What, what, what? Let's partake.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as lief be a condemned man. FIRST and SECOND SERVINGMAN. Wherefore? Wherefore?

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general, Caius Martius.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Why do you say, "thwack our general"?

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: I do not say "thwack our general," but he was always good enough for him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Come, we are fellows and friends. He was ever too hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth on't, before Corioles; he scotched him and notched him like a carbonado.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: An he had been cannibally given, he might have boiled and eaten him too.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: But, more of thy news?

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Why, he is so made on here within as if he were son and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' th' table; no question asked him by any of the senators but they stand bald before him. Our general himself makes a mistress of him, sanctifies himself with's hand, and turns up the white o' th' eye to his discourse. But the bottom of the news is, our general is cut i' th' middle and but one half of what he was yesterday, for the other has half, by the entreaty and grant of the whole table. He'll go, he says, and sowl the porter of Rome gates by th' ears. He will mow all down before him and leave his passage polled.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Do't? He will do't! For look you, sir, he has as many friends as enemies, which friends, sir, as it were, durst not, look you, sir, show themselves, as we term it, his friends whilest he's in directitude.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Directitude? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again, and the man in blood, they will out of their burrows like coneys after rain, and revel all with him.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: But when goes this forward?

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, today, presently. You shall have the drum struck up this afternoon. 'Tis as it were parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Why then, we shall have a stirring world again. This peace is nothing but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Let me have war, say I. It exceeds peace as far as day does night. It's sprightly walking, audible, and full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: 'Tis so, and as war in some sort, may be said to be a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a great maker of cuckolds.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Ay, and it makes men hate one another.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: Reason: because they then less need one another. The wars for my money! I hope to see Romans as cheap as Volscians. They are rising; they are rising.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: In, in, in, in!

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: We hear not of him, neither need we fear him. His remedies are tame-the present peace, And quietness of the people, which before Were in wild hurry. Here do we make his friends Blush that the world goes well, who rather had, Though they themselves did suffer by't, behold Dissentious numbers pest'ring streets than see Our tradesmen singing in their shops and going About their functions friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: We stood to't in good time. Is this Menenius?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: 'Tis he, 'tis he. O, he is grown most kind Of late.-Hail, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Hail to you both.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Your Coriolanus is not much missed But with his friends. The commonwealth doth stand, And so would do were he more angry at it.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: All's well, and might have been much better if He could have temporized.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Where is he, hear you?

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Nay, I hear nothing; His mother and his wife hear nothing from him.

dialogues.speaker: All Citizens
dialogues.line: The gods preserve you both!

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Good e'en, our neighbours.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good e'en to you all, good e'en to you all.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees Are bound to pray for you both.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Live and thrive!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Farewell, kind neighbours. We wished Coriolanus Had loved you as we did.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Now the gods keep you!

dialogues.speaker: Both Tribunes
dialogues.line: Farewell, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: This is a happier and more comely time Than when these fellows ran about the streets Crying confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Caius Martius was A worthy officer i' th' war, but insolent, O'ercome with pride, ambitious, past all thinking Self-loving.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: And affecting one sole throne, without assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: I think not so.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: We should by this, to all our lamentation, If he had gone forth consul, found it so.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The gods have well prevented it, and Rome Sits safe and still without him.

dialogues.speaker: Aedile
dialogues.line: Worthy tribunes, There is a slave, whom we have put in prison, Reports the Volsces with two several powers Are entered in the Roman territories, And with the deepest malice of the war Destroy what lies before 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: 'Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Martius' banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world, Which were inshelled when Martius stood for Rome, And durst not once peep out.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Come, what talk you of Martius?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Go see this rumourer whipped. It cannot be The Volsces dare break with us.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Cannot be? We have record that very well it can, And three examples of the like hath been Before you punish him, where he heard this, Lest you shall chance to whip your information And beat the messenger who bids beware Of what is to be dreaded.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Tell not me. I know this cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the Senate House. Some news is coming That turns their countenances.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: 'Tis this slave- Go whip him 'fore the people's eyes-his raising, Nothing but his report.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Yes, worthy sir, The slave's report is seconded, and more, More fearful, is delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: What more fearful?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: It is spoke freely out of many mouths- How probable I do not know-that Martius, Joined with Aufidius, leads a power 'gainst Rome And vows revenge as spacious as between The young'st and oldest thing.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: This is most likely!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Raised only that the weaker sort may wish Good Martius home again.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: The very trick on 't.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: This is unlikely; He and Aufidius can no more atone Than violent'st contrariety.

dialogues.speaker: Second Messenger
dialogues.line: You are sent for to the Senate. A fearful army, led by Caius Martius Associated with Aufidius, rages Upon our territories, and have already O'erborne their way, consumed with fire and took What lay before them.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: O, you have made good work!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What news? What news?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: You have holp to ravish your own daughters and To melt the city leads upon your pates, To see your wives dishonoured to your noses-

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: What's the news? What's the news?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Your temples burned in their cement, and Your franchises, whereon you stood, confined Into an auger's bore.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Pray now, your news?- You have made fair work, I fear me.-Pray, your news? If Martius should be joined with Volscians-

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: If? He is their god; he leads them like a thing Made by some other deity than Nature, That shapes man better; and they follow him Against us brats with no less confidence Than boys pursuing summer butterflies Or butchers killing flies.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You have made good work, You and your apron-men, you that stood so much Upon the voice of occupation and The breath of garlic eaters!

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: He'll shake your Rome about your ears.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: As Hercules did shake down mellow fruit. You have made fair work.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: But is this true, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Ay, and you'll look pale Before you find it other. All the regions Do smilingly revolt, and who resists Are mocked for valiant ignorance And perish constant fools. Who is't can blame him? Your enemies and his find something in him.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: We are all undone unless The noble man have mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Who shall ask it? The Tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people Deserve such pity of him as the wolf Does of the shepherds. For his best friends, if they Should say "Be good to Rome," they charged him even As those should do that had deserved his hate And therein showed like enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: 'Tis true. If he were putting to my house the brand That should consume it, I have not the face To say "Beseech you, cease."-You have made fair hands, You and your crafts! You have crafted fair!

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: You have brought A trembling upon Rome such as was never S' incapable of help.

dialogues.speaker: Tribunes
dialogues.line: Say not we brought it.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: How? Was it we? We loved him, but like beasts And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters, Who did hoot him out o' th' city.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: But I fear They'll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius, The second name of men, obeys his points As if he were his officer. Desperation Is all the policy, strength, and defence That Rome can make against them.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Here comes the clusters.- And is Aufidius with him? You are they That made the air unwholesome when you cast Your stinking, greasy caps in hooting at Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming, And not a hair upon a soldier's head Which will not prove a whip. As many coxcombs As you threw caps up will he tumble down And pay you for your voices. 'Tis no matter. If he could burn us all into one coal We have deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: All Citizens
dialogues.line: Faith, we hear fearful news.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: For mine own part, When I said banish him, I said 'twas pity.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: And so did I.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: And so did I. And, to say the truth, so did very many of us. That we did we did for the best; and though we willingly consented to his banishment, yet it was against our will.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: You are goodly things, you voices!

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: You have made good work, you and your cry!- Shall's to the Capitol?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: O, ay, what else?

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Go, masters, get you home. Be not dismayed. These are a side that would be glad to have This true which they so seem to fear. Go home, And show no sign of fear.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: The gods be good to us! Come, masters, let's home. I ever said we were i' th' wrong when we banished him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: So did we all. But, come, let's home.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I do not like this news.

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Nor I.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Let's to the Capitol. Would half my wealth Would buy this for a lie!

dialogues.speaker: Sicinius
dialogues.line: Pray let's go.

scenes.location: A camp at a short distance from Rome

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: Do they still fly to th' Roman?

dialogues.speaker: Lieutenant
dialogues.line: I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat, Their talk at table, and their thanks at end; And you are dark'ned in this action, sir, Even by your own.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: I cannot help it now, Unless by using means I lame the foot Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier, Even to my person, than I thought he would When first I did embrace him. Yet his nature In that's no changeling, and I must excuse What cannot be amended.

dialogues.speaker: Lieutenant
dialogues.line: Yet I wish, sir- I mean for your particular-you had not Joined in commission with him, but either Had borne the action of yourself or else To him had left it solely.

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: I understand thee well, and be thou sure, When he shall come to his account, he knows not What I can urge against him, although it seems, And so he thinks and is no less apparent To th' vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly, And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state, Fights dragonlike, and does achieve as soon As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone That which shall break his neck or hazard mine Whene'er we come to our account.

dialogues.speaker: Lieutenant
dialogues.line: Sir, I beseech you, think you he'll carry Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Aufidius
dialogues.line: All places yield to him ere he sits down, And the nobility of Rome are his; The Senators and Patricians love him too. The Tribunes are no soldiers, and their people Will be as rash in the repeal as hasty To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it By sovereignty of nature. First, he was A noble servant to them, but he could not Carry his honours even. Whether 'twas pride, Which out of daily fortune ever taints The happy man; whether defect of judgment, To fail in the disposing of those chances Which he was lord of; or whether nature, Not to be other than one thing, not moving From th' casque to th' cushion, but commanding peace Even with the same austerity and garb As he controlled the war; but one of these- As he hath spices of them all-not all, For I dare so far free him-made him feared, So hated, and so banished. But he has a merit To choke it in the utt'rance. So our virtues Lie in th' interpretation of the time, And power, unto itself most commendable, Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair T' extol what it hath done. One fire drives out one fire, one nail one nail; Rights by rights falter; strengths by strengths do fail. Come, let's away. When, Caius, Rome is thine, Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: No, I'll not go. You hear what he hath said Which was sometime his general, who loved him In a most dear particular. He called me father, But what o' that? Go you that banished him; A mile before his tent, fall down, and knee The way into his mercy. Nay, if he coyed To hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home.

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: He would not seem to know me.

dialogues.speaker: Menenius
dialogues.line: Do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Cominius
dialogues.line: Yet one time he did call me by my name. I urged our old acquaintance, and the drops That we have bled together. "Coriolanus" He would not answer to, forbade all names. He was a kind of nothing, titleless, Till he had forged himself a name i' th' fire Of burning Rome.
